author: By Maya Phillips
title: The Past Pushes Back in 2 Shows With Contemporary Blackness in Mind
description: New productions of “The Merchant of Venice” and “Black No More” aim to reflect our current racial politics. The results are uneven.
content: On a recent weekend, I eagerly set out to see two new productions that prominently center Blackness: the director Arin Arbus’s adaptation of Shakespeare’s “The Merchant of Venice” and “Black No More,” a new musical with a starry creative team that was inspired by a satirical 1931 novel about race in America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: Jets’ Rebuilding Plans Do Not Include Extended Combine Stay
description: Coach Robert Saleh said Jets assistants and scouts would bypass the first days of the combine. The team’s G.M. said it would entertain trades involving its nine picks in the 2022 N.F.L. draft.
content: INDIANAPOLIS — Unlike a majority of his peers on Tuesday and Wednesday, who addressed reporters in person from a lectern set up at the Indiana Convention Center, Jets Coach Robert Saleh sat at the team’s facility at Florham Park, N.J., and answered questions about the team’s pre-draft plans via a video conference call.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Should Tech Stay or Go in Russia?
description: Tech companies seem eager to support Ukraine, but how best to do that isn’t as clear.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. Here is a collection of past columns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Woo
title: Fitbit recalls more than one million smart watches over a burn risk.
description: The company, which is owned by Google, received at least 174 reports of the battery in its Ionic smart watch overheating, leading to 118 reported injuries.
content: Fitbit, the Google-owned maker of health tracking wearables, is voluntarily recalling its Ionic smart watch after more than 100 reports of burn injuries caused by an overheating battery, the Consumer Product Safety Commission said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan K. Stack
title: In Russia, I Learned, Threats Were Always Real
description: A sense of menace floats long enough to make you think you’re paranoid. Sooner or later, what was feared happens. And nobody makes a secret of it.
content: It started with a weekday interview in an office near the Moscow River. The man was a murderer, it was said, but when I asked about the crime, he smirked and said he was framed. I remember his shoes, pointy and shined like glass.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: NoViolet Bulawayo Believes Freedom Begins With Imagination
description: For her 2013 debut novel, Bulawayo was the first Black woman from Africa to become a finalist for the Booker Prize. Her new novel, “Glory,” is a story about a nation on the cusp of revolution.
content: Like many of her compatriots, NoViolet Bulawayo once thought Robert Mugabe would rule Zimbabwe forever.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sherrilyn A. Ifill
title: Who’s Afraid of Ketanji Brown Jackson?
description: The powerful symbolism of her nomination runs deep.
content: The nomination of the first Black woman to serve on the Supreme Court is a long overdue moment of historic consequence. Another glass ceiling has been shattered — and at the most powerful judicial institution in our country. In its 232-year history, only seven of the 115 justices who have served have not been white men. When she is confirmed, Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson will be the eighth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta and Lisa Friedman
title: War Abroad and Politics at Home Push U.S. Climate Action Aside
description: Climate change, a central part of Biden’s agenda, was barely mentioned in the State of the Union. And Europe is confronting its heavy reliance on Russian gas.
content: War and politics are complicating the efforts of the two biggest polluters in history — the United States and Europe — to slow down global warming, just as scientists warn of intensifying hazards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clifford Krauss
title: Exxon Mobil says it plans to leave its last remaining Russian project.
description: BP and Shell announced earlier that they were also seeking to leave the country after its invasion of Ukraine.
content: HOUSTON — Exxon Mobil said Tuesday that it would end its involvement in a large oil and natural gas project in Russia, becoming the latest Western oil company to announce that it is leaving the country after Russia invaded Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Woo and Kevin Roose
title: This Social Club Runs on Crypto Tokens and Vibes
description: Friends With Benefits is a V.I.P. lounge for crypto’s creative class. Is it empty hype or the future of friendship?
content: On a recent afternoon, nine members of the crypto social club Friends With Benefits sat in the historic Bradbury Building in downtown Los Angeles, testing out a new beverage — a flavored, sparkling yerba maté that the group had developed with a coffee company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: Schools Chancellor Pledges to End New York City’s ‘Betrayal’ of Students
description: David Banks vowed in his first major policy address since becoming chancellor to break up bureaucracy, improve literacy and emphasize wellness in schools.
content: The New York City schools chancellor vowed Wednesday to reverse what he called the betrayal of New York City’s public school students by breaking up bureaucracy, getting the city’s hundreds of thousands of low-income students on a path to the middle class and promoting healthy living in schools.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $3 Million Homes in Connecticut, North Carolina and Pennsylvania
description: A Colonial Revival house in Greenwich, a three-bedroom loft condominium in Asheville and a Gilded Age showplace in Pittsburgh.
content: This house, in the Chimney Cove community, abuts an inlet of Indian Harbor, giving many of the rooms a water view. It is about half a mile from Bruce Park, which has a pond, paths for walking and running, and a children’s playground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Spencer Bokat-Lindell
title: Putin Is Brandishing the Nuclear Option. How Serious Is the Threat?
description: The Russian president has ordered his nuclear forces into a higher state of alert — the first time the Kremlin has done so since 1991.
content: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Wednesdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt and Ian Prasad Philbrick
title: Biden for Democracy
description: Ukraine took center stage at the State of the Union.
content: The signature moments of Joe Biden’s rise to the presidency often involved the defense of democracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: NATO Countries Pour Weapons Into Ukraine, Risking Conflict With Russia
description: Brussels is proud to be providing military aid, but Moscow may see it as a dangerous intervention.
content: BRUSSELS — The Dutch are sending rocket launchers for air defense. The Estonians are sending Javelin antitank missiles. The Poles and the Latvians are sending Stinger surface-to-air missiles. The Czechs are sending machine guns, sniper rifles, pistols and ammunition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Burleigh
title: Billionaires Clash Over the Future in a Caribbean Eden
description: A legal feud over a hotel in St. Barts pits development against fragile nature on this tropical Arcadia for the ultrarich. It might also signal a turning point in the hyper-development of the island.
content: Midwinter on the Caribbean island of St. Barts is a kind of second hurricane season. December’s annual landfall of billionaires and celebrities was a Cat 5, with Leonardo DiCaprio, Mike Tyson, the world’s biggest mega-yachts, and Jeff Bezos and his girlfriend canoodling in their bathing suits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: M.L.B. Canceled Games. What Happens Now?
description: Both sides left Florida frustrated, and no date is set for further negotiations. This could take a while.
content: JUPITER, Fla. — On Tuesday, Major League Baseball and the players’ union failed to strike a new labor contract by the league’s self-imposed deadline.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Roach
title: Why Gravel Gardens Are Better Than They Sound
description: Yes, they may require 80 percent less work. But their beauty alone is reason enough to rethink the way you’re gardening now.
content: The phrase “gravel garden” doesn’t resonate with Jeff Epping, although he’s a leading proponent of adopting this planting style, which is beautiful and exceptionally resilient.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: ‘Out of Time’ Review: Once Sidelined, Now Taking Center Stage
description: Five Asian American actors, all over 60, deliver monologues that touch on grief and heritage, on adult children and cultural cancellation.
content: She is absolutely elegant, and completely isolated — a documentarian, microphone clipped to her chest, talking to an unseen camera about the last time she hugged someone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer, Valerie Hopkins and Nick Cumming-Bruce
title: Spurning Rebukes, Russia Escalates Attack on Ukraine as Refugee Ranks Swell
description: There was no sign of possible de-escalation on the sixth day of the invasion, as Russia appeared determined to toughen its tactics against a defiant neighbor.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — Brushing aside international outrage, Russia widened its assault deep inside Ukraine on Tuesday, bombing civilian areas in the two biggest cities, amassing a miles-long convoy near the capital’s doorstep and warning an outside world intent on economic reprisals not to go too far.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: ‘By the Time You Read This, I’ll Have Killed One of Your Husbands’
description: In Gilly Macmillan’s new novel, “The Long Weekend,” a country holiday goes very, very wrong.
content: Erica Ferencik, who writes evocative novels set in extreme landscapes, has placed the hauntingly beautiful GIRL IN ICE (Scout Press, 291 pp., $27) at a research station in the remote reaches of the Arctic Circle. Here a tiny band of scientists studying the ravages of climate change appear to be growing mad — and who could blame them?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo is the designated survivor during the State of the Union.
description: The official is designated to watch the speech from afar in the event catastrophe strikes the Capitol while most of the government leaders are inside.
content: Gina Raimondo, the commerce secretary, will be the so-called designated survivor for the State of the Union, watching from afar when President Biden delivers his speech, according to an administration official.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marcelle Sussman Fischler
title: House Hunting in Canada: Weathered Steel on the Shores of Nova Scotia
description: With remote workers flocking to its bucolic shores, the rapidly growing Atlantic province of Canada isn’t ‘looked at as the poor cousin anymore.’
content: This 2018 property, known as Smith House, sits on just over two acres in the village of Upper Kingsburg, on the South Shore of Nova Scotia, in eastern Canada.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang
title: Hong Kong, Buckling Under Covid, Leaves Its Most Vulnerable in the Cold
description: Poor residents have been forced to choose between infecting their families or sleeping outdoors because of cramped living quarters and a lack of isolation facilities.
content: HONG KONG — For Chan Shun Ki, a cleaner at a construction site in Hong Kong, getting over the coronavirus was the easy part.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: The U.S. extends technology restrictions to Belarus and the Russian oil industry.
description: The Biden administration said the measures would degrade the ability to wage war on Ukraine and would prevent Belarus from channeling forbidden goods to Russia.
content: The Biden administration ramped up restrictions on exporting certain technologies to Russia and Belarus on Wednesday, actions it said would degrade the ability to sustain a military campaign against Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Russia targets civilian areas.
content: On the sixth day of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, the Russian military campaign appeared to have shifted toward targeting civilian areas with increasingly powerful weapons. The U.N. said that at least 136 civilians, including 13 children, had been killed so far. Volodymyr Zelensky, the Ukrainian president, has accused Russia of war crimes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Teo Bugbee
title: ‘The Long Walk’ Review: A Ghostly Future in Laos
description: This Laotian drama from Mattie Do presents a world where spirits linger on into a future that has been shaped by technology.
content: The Laotian drama “The Long Walk” takes a languid look around a near-future dystopia where fighter jets leave smoke trails in the sky and government authorities track missing people using microchips embedded in their bodies. In this reality, a spiritual, occult world exists underneath the noses of officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: The World Is Awash in Plastic. Nations Plan a Treaty to Fix That.
description: The new pact would be legally binding and could go beyond cleaning up plastic waste to curbs on future production.
content: With the bang of a gavel made of recycled plastic and a standing ovation, representatives of 175 nations agreed on Wednesday to begin writing a global treaty that would restrict the explosive growth of plastic pollution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Barry Bauman, Restoration Artist and Detective, Dies at 73
description: A noted conservator, he peeled back paintings’ hidden layers and sometimes uncovered fakes, most notably a portrait wrongly thought to be of Mary Todd Lincoln.
content: For three decades, a portrait of Mary Todd Lincoln hung in the governor’s mansion in Springfield, Ill. Mrs. Lincoln was said to have commissioned Francis Bicknell Carpenter, a celebrated painter who lived in the White House for six months in 1864, to paint it as a gift for her husband, President Abraham Lincoln.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Granville
title: Stocks rise as Powell signals steadiness, and oil prices continue to march higher.
description: The rise in energy prices appeared to be tied to concerns about production limits and potential disruptions to Russian supplies.
content: Stocks in the U.S. jumped on Wednesday after the chair of the Federal Reserve said central bankers “will proceed carefully” with plans to raise interest rates amid high inflation and uncertainty created by the war in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: Set Your Schedule in Your Smartphone’s Free Calendar
description: As daily life feels more familiar, apps from Apple and Google can keep you organized and get you to your in-person events on time.
content: If your phone’s personal calendar app hasn’t gotten much use in the past two years of social distancing and working from home, it might be time to brush up. Here’s a quick guide to tools in Apple’s iOS Calendar and Google Calendar that help you plan your social life, get to your events on time, share your hybrid work schedule with family and more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Prosecutors Open Arguments Against Defendant in First Jan. 6 Trial
description: Guy Reffitt recorded himself as he entered the Capitol with zip ties and a pistol. “We’re taking the Capitol before the day is over, ripping them out by their hair,” he said.
content: WASHINGTON — On the afternoon of Jan. 6, 2021, a man believed by the authorities to be a member of a Texas militia walked from the Ellipse in Washington, where President Donald J. Trump had been speaking about election fraud, to the Capitol. He was wearing what he described as his “full battle rattle”: body armor, a helmet fixed with a camera, a set of plastic hand ties and a .40-caliber pistol at his hip.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘How a Book Is Made: Ink, Paper and a 200,000-Pound Printer’
description: In this lesson, students will learn from videos, photos and text about the process of making a book. Then, they will design an explainer of that process, or research how something else gets made.
content: Featured Article: “How a Book Is Made: Ink, Paper and a 200,000-Pound Printer” by Elizabeth A. Harris with photography and video by Thomas Prior
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: Powerful Ex-Illinois House Speaker Is Indicted on Federal Charges
description: Michael J. Madigan, who for decades steered Democratic politics in Illinois, was charged with racketeering and accused of using his office for personal gain.
content: CHICAGO — Michael J. Madigan, the former speaker of the Illinois House of Representatives who for decades wielded extraordinary power over Democratic politics in the state, was indicted on Wednesday on federal racketeering, bribery, wire fraud and extortion charges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: Justice Dept. Announces Task Force to Go After Russian Oligarchs
description: The task force adds to the raft of actions that Western leaders have taken in recent days in an effort to undercut Vladimir V. Putin and the politically connected elite in Russia.
content: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department announced on Wednesday the creation of a task force to go after billionaire oligarchs who have aided President Vladimir V. Putin in his invasion of Ukraine, part of an effort by the United States to seize and freeze the assets of those who have violated sanctions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dorie Greenspan
title: Mistakes Happen. In the Kitchen, That Can Be the Best Thing.
description: For her final column, Dorie Greenspan shares how a recipe misstep led to perfectly imperfect chocolate thumbprint cookies.
content: I love the famous story of Julia Child’s dropping a hunk of meat on the kitchen floor, scooping it up and carrying on. It doesn’t matter to me that it never happened — Julia told me that it didn’t when I asked her about it years ago — it’s still fun to imagine the scene. Her timing would be perfect and her movements grand. As she would thump the food back onto the counter, she would smile, and it would have the complicity of a wink, drawing us in. Then, in her breathy voice with her quirky cadence, she would say the lines that are quoted so often: “Always remember: If you’re alone in the kitchen and you drop the lamb, you can always just pick it up. Who’s going to know?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: Putin’s War to Bring Ukraine to Heel Unites Eastern Europe in Alarm
description: Many countries fear that the Russian leader’s efforts to turn back the clock and reclaim a sphere of influence lost at the end of the Cold War could spell disaster for them.
content: PODBORSKO, Poland — Scattered around the forest in Poland like archaeological ruins, the crumbling concrete bunkers for decades stored Soviet nuclear warheads. Today, they store only memories — deeply painful for Poland, joyous for the Kremlin — of the vanished empire that President Vladimir V. Putin wants to rebuild, starting with his war in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Biden Talks Business in the State of the Union
description: From inflation to manufacturing and technology, the president’s annual address to Congress was heavy on economic issues.
content: President Biden led his first State of the Union address yesterday with a promise to make Vladimir Putin pay for invading Ukraine and praise for the Ukrainian resistance. When he turned to domestic issues, a fair amount of his hour-long speech focused on business and the economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Winnie Hu
title: Raising Crosswalks to Make Deadly Intersections Safer in New York
description: City officials want to install 100 raised crosswalks every year as part of a larger effort to redesign dangerous intersections.
content: The white-striped crosswalk sits on top of a hump of asphalt.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Enigma of Big Thief
description: A conversation about the space the breakout Brooklyn band occupies in contemporary indie-rock circles, and its latest album.
content: The Brooklyn band Big Thief has become one of the indie-rock breakout success stories of recent years. With its evolving indie-folk sound, the band has inspired both passionate fandom and committed detractors — it is an intimately-scaled band that inspires big feelings. Its fifth album, “Dragon New Warm Mountain I Believe In You,” is out now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Klein
title: Biden Has the Right Idea, but the Wrong Words
description: A Biden doctrine is emerging, even if he got only halfway there in his State of the Union address.
content: President Biden’s State of the Union address on Tuesday night sounded like two speeches grafted together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: D.I.Y.
description: Are you a fan of do-it-yourself projects? What have you made or fixed this way?
content: According to a recent Times article, a new generation of influencers has discovered D.I.Y., or do-it-yourself, and is using things like spray paint, hot glue and thrift-store finds to spruce up their spaces on a tiny budget.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: The Women of ‘The Dropout’ Want to Humanize Elizabeth Holmes
description: In a group interview, Elizabeth Meriwether, Amanda Seyfried and Rebecca Jarvis discuss the new Hulu series about the fall of Theranos and their efforts to reveal the woman beneath the turtleneck.
content: “I really wanted to trust her,” Amanda Seyfried said. “If it had all worked out, it would have been so amazing.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Diverse Artists to Write and Illustrate New Dr. Seuss-Inspired Books
description: Each of the new books will be inspired by an unpublished sketch by Dr. Seuss, whose whimsical imagery has drawn new scrutiny since his estate pulled six titles from circulation last year.
content: Unpublished sketches by Dr. Seuss will serve as the inspiration for a new series of children’s books to be written and illustrated by a diverse group of emerging artists, the company that oversees the author’s estate said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: The coronavirus invades cells in the penis and testicles of monkeys, researchers discover.
description: The study suggests that symptoms such as erectile dysfunction reported by some Covid patients may be caused directly by the virus.
content: The coronavirus may infect tissue within the male genital tract, new research on rhesus macaques shows. The finding suggests that symptoms like erectile dysfunction reported by some Covid patients may be caused directly by the virus, not by inflammation or fever that often accompany the disease.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Christina Goldbaum and Najim Rahim
title: Taliban Search Operation Echoes Resented U.S. Tactics
description: An intrusive sweep that has spanned several provinces risks alienating Afghans and fueling the insurgency the new government is trying to stop.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — Trucks with heavy machine guns stopped at street corners, unloading men in camouflage carrying radios and assault rifles. Going door to door, they barged into homes, tossed open drawers and pored through cellphones — looking for any connection to an armed insurgency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Putin’s Maestro, and the Limits of Cultural Exchange in Wartime
description: The Russian conductor Valery Gergiev and the diva Anna Netrebko have lost engagements because of their ties to Putin, as geopolitics and music collide once again.
content: A conductor, perceived to be aligned with the opposition in wartime, pushed from his podium in disgrace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Anderson
title: High-speed trains departing Russia for Finland are packed.
description: Once starved for passengers, the trains are now full, and negotiations are underway between state-owned Finnish and Russian rail companies to increase the service.
content: Until this weekend, the daily high-speed trains from St. Petersburg to Helsinki would typically transport far fewer than the several hundred passengers each could accommodate. But on Saturday, a wave of travelers looking to leave Russia started packing trains destined for Finland.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko and Anton Troianovski
title: A War the Kremlin Tried to Disguise Becomes a Hard Reality for Russians
description: Moscow posted a death toll from its attack on Ukraine for the first time, and Russians who long avoided politics are now grappling with the fact that their country is fighting a deadly conflict.
content: SOCHI, Russia — On Feb. 23, Razil Malikov, a tank driver in the Russian Army, called his family and said he would be home soon; his unit’s military drills in Crimea were just about wrapping up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz and Richard Pérez-Peña
title: First Ukraine City Falls as Russia Strikes More Civilian Targets
description: Russian forces seized the southern city of Kherson and besieged other cities, with casualties and destruction mounting, as Western sanctions tightened their vise grip on Russia’s economy.
content: ODESSA, Ukraine — Russian forces on Wednesday seized the first major Ukrainian city in their onslaught, the strategic port of Kherson, as they stepped up bombardment of civilian targets across the country, put other cities under siege and pushed to encircle and cut off the capital, Kyiv.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leah Askarinam and Blake Hounshell
title: A Crisis Abroad, and a Presidential Address and an Election at Home
description: As President Biden delivers his first formal State of the Union address, Russia’s invasion of Ukraine escalates and the midterms begin in earnest in Texas.
content: Russian missiles are terrorizing Ukraine. President Biden hopes to rally the nation in his first formal State of the Union address. And the first votes of the 2022 midterm elections will be counted tonight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lev Golinkin
title: The Ukraine of My Childhood Is Being Erased
description: Ukraine’s history is filled with waves of repression.
content: I grew up in a land of lies and bones, with the dead being erased or subsumed by the Kremlin, which refused to see Ukraine as a nation, imposing a Soviet identity over us all.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Modern Love Podcast: You May Think You Know Your Parents
description: That is, until you have a startling revelation about them in adulthood.
content: Ariel Sabar was visiting his parents in his childhood home in California, when he awoke one morning to high-pitched giggles coming from his parents’ room.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Gaming Giant Behind Fortnite Buys Bandcamp, an Indie Music Haven
description: Epic Games is acquiring an online music platform that has been embraced by musicians for its eclectic offerings and a payment system that favors artists.
content: The world of independent music got a jolt on Wednesday when Bandcamp, the platform that has been a haven for musicians during the pandemic, announced that it had been acquired by Epic Games, the company behind blockbuster online video games like Fortnite.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Also at Stake in Ukraine: the Future of Two Orthodox Churches
description: The Russian church hopes to reunite with the independent Ukrainian branch under a single patriarch in Moscow that would allow it to control the holiest sites of Orthodoxy in the Slavic world.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — Standing in the cobblestone courtyard of a medieval monastery, with an icy wind whipping his black robes and artillery shells booming in the distance, Archbishop Yefrem is tormented by the war that is slowly engulfing his city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farhad Manjoo
title: Putin No Longer Seems Like a Master of Disinformation
description: Putin Doesn’t Seem Like a Wizard of Disinformation Now
content: Late last week, as it started to become clear that Russia’s invasion of Ukraine had united much of the world in condemnation of Vladimir Putin, I turned on my favorite international propagandist network, Russia Today, to see how the horror was being justified.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev
title: Venezuela’s Leader Trades Old Guard for Slick Technocrats to Keep Power
description: A new generation of cosmopolitan Venezuelan officials has allowed President Nicolás Maduro to halt the economic collapse and remain in power, at the cost of fostering potential future challenges to his rule.
content: PUERTO CABELLO, Venezuela — His morning jogs draw fans seeking selfies. His Dracula-themed social media stunts have attracted nearly a million followers. And when he ran for re-election as governor of his state in Venezuela in November, he won in a landslide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Thursday Briefing: Russia Seizes Kherson
description: A strategically important city falls.
content: Russian forces swept into the strategically important city of Kherson on Wednesday, the mayor said, in what could be a significant moment in the battle for the country’s south. Explosions struck the capital, Kyiv, and Russian troops continued to lay siege to Kharkiv. Here are the latest updates, and maps that show Russia’s advance on Kyiv.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee, Emily Schmall and Sameer Yasir
title: ‘We Are on Our Side’: Across Asia, a Mixed Reaction to Ukraine War
description: While most American allies in the region have fallen in line, authoritarian governments and those with weaker ties to the West have been more reluctant to act.
content: SINGAPORE — Much of the world has united against Russia in the aftermath of its incursion into Ukraine. Envoys have walked out of meetings rather than listen to a top Russian diplomat speak. Western nations have been in near lock step on international sanctions. Bartenders are banning Russian vodka.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Naomi Huffman
title: Autofiction for People Who Think They’re Sick of It
description: Claire-Louise Bennett’s second novel, “Checkout 19,” centers on the passionate collision between reader, writer and book.
content: CHECKOUT 19By Claire-Louise Bennett
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Maslin Nir
title: As New York Students Shed Masks, Elation Mixes With Trepidation
description: On the first day for some school districts to go maskless, there was disagreement at one Long Island school over whether the change came too soon or was overdue.
content: SANDS POINT, N.Y. — Just before classes began on Wednesday morning, Jordan Goldberg, a fifth grader at Guggenheim Elementary School on Long Island, strode through the doors and stopped short.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: Biden Must Not Allow Ukraine to Fall
description: Zelensky’s courage gives the administration a rare opportunity.
content: In the cause of freedom, the world has found in Volodymyr Zelensky its most Churchillian figure in decades. “I need ammunition, not a ride” — the Ukrainian president’s spirited reply to an American offer to spirit him to safety — is a line for the ages. His inspiring appearances on the streets of Kyiv recall Britain’s wartime prime minister during the Blitz, personifying his nation’s determination to resist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Weise
title: Amazon plans to shut down more than 50 brick-and-mortar stores.
description: The closures affect its bookstores and Amazon 4-Star locations, but not Whole Foods or Amazon Fresh.
content: Amazon is closing more than 50 of its physical retail stores, including two dozen bookstores and more than 30 Amazon 4-Star stores selling general merchandise, the company said Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lulu Garcia-Navarro, Thomas L. Friedman, Ross Douthat and Yara Bayoumy
title: Four Times Opinion Writers on War in Ukraine: ‘It Is Very Clear Putin Has No Plan B’
description: Lulu Garcia-Navarro, Thomas Friedman, Ross Douthat and Yara Bayoumy discuss what could come next in Ukraine.
content: We’re headed into the second week of Russia’s war on Ukraine. Russian forces have escalated their assault on Ukraine’s second largest city, Kharkiv. With its ground forces bogged down by logistical failures, Moscow has turned to aerial bombardment of civilian targets across Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Review: A Los Angeles Troupe in Search of Choreographic Vision
description: Bodytraffic’s program at the Joyce Theater leaves you contemplating some problems of contemporary dance.
content: Bodytraffic was founded 15 years ago by two Juilliard graduates who had moved to Los Angeles and started commissioning choreographers they liked. In the years since, the troupe has attracted attention and a stream of well-trained, committed dancers. But those dancers need works to perform, and the ones on the program that the company brought to the Joyce Theater on Tuesday are dispiriting. They’re the kind that send you to program notes in vain hopes of clarification, the sort that might leave you wondering what’s wrong with contemporary dance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan
title: The C.D.C. no longer recommends universal contact tracing.
description: “The updated guidance is in response to changes in the nature of the pandemic and the increasing availability of new tools to prevent transmission and mitigate illness,” the agency said.
content: Almost two years after the director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention called for 100,000 contact tracers to contain the coronavirus, the C.D.C. said this week that it no longer recommends universal case investigation and contact tracing. Instead it encourages health departments to focus those practices on high-risk settings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Officer in Breonna Taylor Raid Says He Mistook Police Gunfire for a Suspect’s
description: Brett Hankison is on trial over charges that he endangered Ms. Taylor’s neighbors. His bullets did not strike anyone, and he testified that he had done nothing wrong in the fatal police raid.
content: The former detective who is facing charges of recklessly endangering Breonna Taylor’s neighbors during the fatal police raid on her apartment testified at his trial on Wednesday, saying that he wrongly interpreted the sound of his fellow officers spraying bullets into Ms. Taylor’s apartment as that of a suspect firing a rifle at the police.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: Before Invasion, Ukraine’s Lithium Wealth Was Drawing Global Attention
description: Chinese and Australian investors had been lining up to explore for lithium, a metal that is critical to batteries and the world’s transition to clean energy.
content: Deep below the ground in Ukraine, where Russia continues to mount an aggressive attack, lies vast, untapped mineral wealth that could hold the keys to a lucrative, clean-energy future for the Eastern European nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: How the Coronavirus Steals the Sense of Smell
description: The virus does not infect nerve cells that detect odors, researchers have found. Instead, it attacks nearby supporting cells.
content: Few of Covid-19’s peculiarities have piqued as much interest as anosmia, the abrupt loss of smell that has become a well-known hallmark of the disease. Covid patients lose this sense even without a stuffy nose; the loss can make food taste like cardboard and coffee smell noxious, occasionally persisting after other symptoms have resolved.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong and Julian E. Barnes
title: China Asked Russia to Delay Ukraine War Until After Olympics, U.S. Officials Say
description: A Western intelligence report indicates that Chinese officials had some level of direct knowledge about President Vladimir V. Putin’s war plans or intentions.
content: WASHINGTON — A Western intelligence report said senior Chinese officials told senior Russian officials in early February not to invade Ukraine before the end of the Winter Olympics in Beijing, according to senior Biden administration officials and a European official.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Ashford
title: Children in some New York day care centers can go maskless Wednesday.
description: The change was announced by Gov. Kathy Hochul on Sunday along with the news that she was rolling back the statewide school mask mandate.
content: Children will be allowed to shed their masks on Wednesday in some New York State day care and child care centers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: The Biden administration plans to release a new coronavirus strategy on Wednesday.
description: The White House will unveil President Biden’s new coronavirus response strategy on Wednesday, a lengthy document intended to usher the nation into what some are calling a “new normal” — even as the possibility of another deadly variant looms.
content: The White House will unveil President Biden’s new coronavirus response strategy on Wednesday, a lengthy document intended to usher the nation into what some are calling a “new normal” — even as the possibility of another deadly variant looms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Autherine Lucy Foster, First Black Student at U. of Alabama, Dies at 92
description: Her career there lasted only three days; attacked by mobs, she was suspended and then expelled. Today, a campus building is named in her honor.
content: Autherine Lucy had no particular desire to be a civil rights pioneer. Growing up as the youngest of 10 children in an Alabama farm family, she simply wanted to get the best education her state could offer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Monika Pronczuk and Dan Bilefsky
title: The E.U. is expected to grant blanket protection to Ukrainian refugees.
description: Under the measure, which would apply to all Ukrainian nationals, refugees would be granted the right to live, study and work across the 27-member bloc for up to three years.
content: The European Union is expected to grant temporary protection to all Ukrainians, as record numbers of refugees fleeing Russia’s invasion move into the bloc, in what rights advocates warn could become a massive humanitarian crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Weekly Accessible Learning Activities: Ukraine, Advice, Cooking Insects
description: Each week we spotlight five student activities created for a broad range of learners based on reporting in The New York Times.
content: Each Wednesday we shine a spotlight on five student activities that support a broad range of learners. In this week’s roundup of accessible activities, we invite students to learn about pedestrian deaths during the pandemic, reflect on receiving good advice, share their reactions to the war in Ukraine, make observations about a photograph and consider if they would ever eat bugs for a better environment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Reyburn
title: Magritte Sets Record With $79.7 Million Sale at Sotheby’s
description: “L’empire des lumières” (1961), one of a series by the Surrealist, was auctioned during a bustling London art week.
content: One of René Magritte’s famed “Empire of Light” canvases sold Wednesday for 59.4 million pounds with fees, or about $79.7 million, almost three times the auction high price at auction for a work by the Belgian Surrealist artist. Certain to raise at least $60 million, courtesy of a guaranteed minimum price financed by Sotheby’s, the 1961 painting was sought by three bidders, all represented by Sotheby’s specialists on telephones in London.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: Unity in a Foreign Policy Crisis, but Questions Still to be Answered
description: President Biden emphasized allies’ resolve in his State of the Union address, but acknowledged Russia may not be deterred from further efforts to reconstitute the Soviet bloc.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden’s challenge on Tuesday night was to unite Americans behind his confrontation with a brutal Russian leader who has shattered more than three decades of post-Cold War peace without setting off fears that the return of superpower conflict will inflict an unacceptable cost.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith and Tariq Panja
title: Chelsea Is for Sale, Its Russian Owner Says
description: As British lawmakers take aim at wealthy Russians, Roman Abramovich confirmed he was seeking to sell the Premier League team he has owned since 2003.
content: LONDON — Roman Abramovich, the Russian oligarch whose vast fortune transformed Chelsea into a global soccer powerhouse, confirmed Wednesday that he is actively seeking to sell the team. He has set a deadline of Friday for interested parties to submit “indicative offers” for the club he has owned for almost two decades, and is said to be seeking at least $2.5 billion for the club.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Biden’s approval ratings are lagging as he delivers the State of the Union.
description: President Biden faces lagging approval ratings as he delivers his first State of the Union address on Tuesday evening.
content: President Biden faces lagging approval ratings as he delivers his first State of the Union address on Tuesday evening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Robert Hicks, Blockbuster Author and Battlefield Savior, Dies at 71
description: He published “The Widow of the South” to promote his real passion: reclaiming a Tennessee Civil War site’s complicated history.
content: Robert Hicks, an ebullient, entrancing raconteur who rebuilt an 18th-century log cabin, amassed a renowned collection of 19th-century antiques and saved a Civil War battlefield from being overrun by strip malls, but who is perhaps best remembered for writing a blockbuster novel that drew on all those experiences, died on Friday at his home near Franklin, Tenn. He was 71.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Molly Young
title: This Memoir About the Contradictions of Grief Plays by Its Own Rules
description: The novelist Kathryn Davis’s personal and time-shuffling new book, “Aurelia, Aurélia,” is about the death of her husband.
content: There are memoirs in which you learn the facts of a person’s life, and then there are memoirs in which you are a chip implanted in the author’s brain. In the case of Kathryn Davis’s memoir, you are a chip. “Aurelia, Aurélia” is only 108 pages long, and a mystery presents itself: How could so much consciousness be packed into such a small object?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Knvul Sheikh
title: Will Cutting Out Dairy Give Me Clear Skin?
description: Maybe, experts say, but the science is mixed.
content: Q: Does cutting out dairy really help control acne?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivek Shankar and Christine Chung
title: Michigan, Illinois and parts of Hawaii join the list of places that are easing virus restrictions.
description: The moves come as the country’s Omicron wave recedes and after the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention updated its mask guidance.
content: Several counties in Hawaii, the city of Boston and the states of Michigan, Illinois and Delaware are the latest places to lift some coronavirus-related restrictions as the Omicron wave recedes and after the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention offered guidelines that suggest that most Americans can stop wearing masks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Bong Joon Ho and Ryusuke Hamaguchi on Oscar Surprise ‘Drive My Car’
description: The Korean filmmaker and the Japanese director have long admired each other. The two explain why Hamaguchi’s best-picture nominee resonates.
content: In January 2020, just weeks before his film “Parasite” would make Oscar history, the director Bong Joon Ho was in Tokyo doing a magazine interview. By that point in what had become a very long press tour, Bong had dutifully sat for dozens of profiles, but at least this one offered a little bit of intrigue: Bong’s interviewer was Ryusuke Hamaguchi, a rising director in his own right.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan and Ali Watkins
title: N.Y.P.D. Sergeant Pleads Guilty to Assault Charges in Violent Arrests
description: Sgt. Phillip Wong punched one handcuffed man after being spit at and knelt on another who had taunted him with anti-Asian slurs.
content: A veteran New York City police sergeant pleaded guilty on Wednesday to misdemeanor assault charges stemming from attacks on handcuffed men who had provoked him during two separate arrests, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Benzel
title: Shirley Hughes, Whose Books Depicted Children’s Mini-Dramas, Dies at 94
description: Beloved in her native England, she wrote and illustrated more than 70 books for children of all ages, with millions of copies sold worldwide. She was honored by the queen.
content: Shirley Hughes, a British author and illustrator whose picture books about the quotidian dramas and escapades of children entertained and reassured generations of young readers and their parents, died on Friday at her home in West London. She was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: Dua Lipa Brings Her Lockdown Anthems to the Arena
description: The pop star’s second album, “Future Nostalgia,” is ambitious and impressive. Onstage, the production didn’t match the LP’s ecstasy.
content: Many of the best Dua Lipa songs start with an easily absorbable concept — “Physical,” “Levitating,” “Cool” — and emanate outward from there. Her music is fleet, stomping and appealingly icy: industrial-grade club-pop that’s mindful of history while flaunting the latest in polish and panache.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Precious Fondren
title: The head of a popular brewery in Brooklyn resigns after his attacks on vaccine mandates drew criticism.
description: Josh Stylman, a founder of Threes Brewing who called vaccine mandates “crimes against humanity,” said he was leaving so he could speak his mind freely.
content: The chief executive of a popular brewery in Brooklyn, who attracted wide criticism last month when he called coronavirus vaccine mandates a “crime against humanity” and drew comparisons to the Jim Crow South and Nazi Germany, is leaving his post, the company announced on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Broadway’s Cort Theater Will Have a New Name: James Earl Jones
description: The landmark theater will be renamed in honor of the 91-year-old actor who has made 21 Broadway appearances and won two competitive Tony Awards.
content: The Shubert Organization, which is Broadway’s biggest landlord, will rename one of its 17 theaters after the actor James Earl Jones, fulfilling a promise made when Black artists pressed for greater recognition in the wake of the 2020 protests against societal racism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger
title: Twitter Wants to Reinvent Itself, by Merging the Old With the New
description: The company is undertaking a far-reaching effort to change how it works. For some, it is an echo of their early idealism and a vision for what the internet could have been.
content: In 2008, the handful of employees working for Twitter reached an impasse. Some were focused on preparing for a surge of new users to their social media platform. But one developer argued for another approach: Their platform, he said, shouldn’t be a platform at all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: impede
description: This word has appeared in 132 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word impede has appeared in 132 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Nov. 17 in “An Indigenous Women’s Softball Team Beats Opponents, and Machismo” by Adam Williams:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penn Bullock
title: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tania Ganguli
title: Star-Studded Lakers Are Fighting Just to Make the Playoffs
description: LeBron James is defiant, but the fans are booing, and the season might be lost.
content: LOS ANGELES — The Lakers are on the verge of missing the N.B.A. playoffs. Their fans are booing and heckling them at home. They haven’t won since the All-Star break. They’ve won only three games out of their last 13.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Amelia Earhart’s Helmet Sells for $825,000
description: The leather aviator’s helmet she wore on record-setting flights in the 1920s sold to a big money buyer.
content: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. Today we’ll follow up on two tantalizing stories you might have read, but now there are new details you’ll want to know about. One story was about the leather helmet that Amelia Earhart wore when she flew across the Atlantic. The other story was about a former Harlem drug kingpin who became an informant and was killed last fall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley and Matt Stevens
title: Vladimir Potanin, Russian Oligarch, Steps Down as Guggenheim Trustee
description: Mr. Potanin, one of the richest men in Russia and a Guggenheim Museum donor for decades, is the latest oligarch affected by widening outrage over the war in Ukraine.
content: For 20 years, Vladimir O. Potanin, one of Russia’s richest men, has been a key supporter of the Guggenheim Museum, serving as a trustee and major benefactor while his foundation sponsored exhibitions, including the current show in New York about the Russian artist Wassily Kandinsky.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Jan. 6 Panel Subpoenas Lawyers Who Worked to Overturn Trump’s Loss
description: The House committee issued six subpoenas to people who worked on legal aspects of the former president’s bid to invalidate the 2020 election.
content: WASHINGTON — The House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol on Tuesday subpoenaed a half-dozen lawyers and other allies of former President Donald J. Trump who promoted false claims about widespread fraud in the 2020 election and worked to overturn his loss.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 5 Minutes That Will Make You Love Wagner
description: Rian Johnson, Patti Smith, Alex Ross and others offer favorite highlights of a composer best known for his sprawling length.
content: In the past we’ve chosen the five minutes or so we would play to make our friends fall in love with classical music, piano, opera, cello, Mozart, 21st-century composers, violin, Baroque music, sopranos, Beethoven, flute, string quartets, tenors, Brahms, choral music, percussion, symphonies, Stravinsky, trumpet, Maria Callas, Bach, the organ, mezzo-sopranos and music for dance.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Full Transcript of Biden’s State of the Union Address
description: The president spoke about the war in Ukraine, the coronavirus pandemic, the economy and more in his State of the Union speech.
content: President Biden delivered his annual State of the Union address on Tuesday to a joint session of Congress. The following is a transcript of his remarks, as recorded by The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: ‘Against the Ice’ Review: Snow Buddies
description: A hard-core first half is deflated by sleepy melodrama and a formulaic script in this adventure film about the Danish explorer Ejnar Mikkelsen.
content: Streaming on Netflix, “Against the Ice” gives the mission to secure Denmark’s claim to Greenland the survival flick treatment, and the explorer Ejnar Mikkelsen a glow up in the form of Nikolaj Coster-Waldau (“Game of Thrones”).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: Starbucks Is Moving to Oust Workers in Buffalo, Union Supporters Say
description: Some employees who back unionization efforts have been told they must increase their work availability or leave. The company cites scheduling issues.
content: Workers at Starbucks stores in Buffalo are accusing the company of retaliating against union supporters by telling some of them they may have to leave the company if they cannot increase their work availability.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: French Female Directors Continue Hot Streak at Rendez-Vous Festival
description: The series returns in-person with an especially strong slate of work by Frenchwomen — fitting, given their run of honors at top festivals.
content: Sex and the city, false identities and love triangles feature prominently in this year’s Rendez-Vous With French Cinema, an annual showcase of contemporary French filmmaking held by Film at Lincoln Center.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: An Offer That Was Engineered to Be Rejected
description: Commissioner Rob Manfred boasted of his streak of successful labor negotiations, but by effectively creating a salary cap he had to know this deal would fail.
content: Rob Manfred hailed himself last month as a master negotiator, boasting of his flawless record in collective bargaining: four labor deals and no missed games since his hiring by Major League Baseball in 1998. If anyone had a problem with him now, Manfred strongly suggested, it was on them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Paralympics Will Allow Russian Athletes to Compete
description: The International Paralympic Committee said athletes from Russia and Belarus could compete as neutrals when the Games open this week after deciding it had no legal grounds to bar them.
content: BEIJING — Organizers of the Beijing Winter Paralympics will allow athletes from Russia and Belarus to compete when the Games open this week, despite mounting pressure to exclude Russia and its teams from global sports as punishment for the country’s invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Who won, who lost and what was too close to call in the Texas primaries.
description: The governor’s race is set, but the two-term attorney general is heading into a runoff. Some House primaries were too close to call. Here’s what we know.
content: The Texas primaries on Tuesday officially opened the 2022 midterm election season, and while several important races remained too close to call early Wednesday morning, the contours were becoming clearer. Here is what we know so far.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Malia Wollan
title: How to Design a Bike Lane
description: Create obvious and clearly marked pathways. Devise routes with destinations — parks, schools, commercial corridors, beaches.
content: “The materials themselves should send the message that this is where cyclists belong,” says Zabe Bent, the design director at the National Association of City Transportation Officials, an organization that published a set of national bike-lane design standards in 2010, which has since been endorsed by the Federal Highway Administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Suhasini Raj
title: An Indian student was killed while getting food for others sheltering in Kharkiv.
description: Naveen Shekharappa was killed when he left a bunker in Kharkiv to fetch food, officials and his family members said.
content: NEW DELHI — The death of an Indian student in the fighting in Ukraine on Tuesday has brought into focus India’s challenge of evacuating nearly 20,000 of its citizens who were stranded in the country when Russia’s invasion began.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Cain
title: You Are Cordially Invited to Our Wedding … on Wednesday
description: A new trend to come out of this year’s wedding boom: saying so long to stuffy old Saturdays and booking your big day on a weekday.
content: Read more about the 2022 wedding boom in our ongoing Year of the Wedding series.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Eder and Ben Protess
title: Trump Hotel Chief, Hired With Big Ambitions, Leaves a Shrinking Brand
description: Eric Danziger was the only outsider to lead the Trump hotel group. His departure, for family reasons, comes as the Trumps pursue a future beyond hotels.
content: Donald J. Trump’s top hotel executive is leaving the company as its five-star signature hotel brand has taken a back seat to other moneymaking ventures by the former president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Looking for an Endgame in Ukraine
description: Three scenarios for a place where our support for the Ukrainians, our sense of our own interests and the realities of Russian power might converge.
content: Let’s start with a very cold-sounding observation. The first week of Vladimir Putin’s invasion of Ukraine has been the best week for American grand strategy in a very long time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Powell Says Rates Are Headed Higher, Even as Ukraine Poses Uncertainty
description: Jerome Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, said he would support a quarter-point increase at the March meeting.
content: Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, told lawmakers on Wednesday that the central bank is poised to lift interest rates at its meeting this month as it tries to cool down high inflation — saying that while Russia’s invasion of Ukraine is ramping up economic uncertainty, it isn’t yet shaking the Fed off its course.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Allen
title: A Conductor Brings Nearly a Century of Experience to Beethoven
description: Herbert Blomstedt, 94 and leading the New York Philharmonic this week, discusses the famous opening of the Fifth Symphony.
content: Herbert Blomstedt just keeps on going. The Illinois-born, Swedish conductor is 94, and he maintains a schedule that musicians half his age might blanch at.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi
title: The U.N. General Assembly passes a resolution strongly condemning Russia’s invasion.
description: The four-page document calls for an immediate halt to the conflict, urges diplomatic negotiations for a peaceful resolution and says Russia’s territorial gain through force will not be recognized.
content: The United Nations General Assembly adopted a resolution on Wednesday condemning Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, with the support of 141 countries out of 193 and a standing ovation in the chamber.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: New Law Overhauling N.Y.’s Parole System Is Being Ignored, Lawyers Say
description: The so-called “Less Is More Act” took effect this week, but lawyers for dozens being detained for parole violations said in a court filing that the state corrections department was disregarding parts of it.
content: When Kathy Hochul signed her first marquee piece of criminal justice legislation in September, it was hailed by prisoners’ rights groups and advocates as the most transformative overhaul to a state parole system in the nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Argument'
title: Alexander Vindman on Why It’s the ‘Beginning of the End’ for Putin
description: The former Ukraine expert for the National Security Council shares his take on the Russia-Ukraine war.
content: In the days since Vladimir Putin ordered Russian forces to invade Ukraine, its citizens have taken up arms to defend their borders and their right to self-determination. Where is the rest of the world in all of this?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitie Kelly
title: Remember Going Out? These Perfumes Promise to Take You Back
description: A rundown of scents, with common notes of tobacco and leather, inspired by famous nightclubs and jostling bodies.
content: The transporting abilities of scent are often invoked but just as frequently misunderstood. “Smells aren’t better at retrieving memories than other stimuli, like things we see or hear,” says Dr. Pamela Dalton, an experimental psychologist at the Monell Chemical Senses Center in Philadelphia. “But the memories that smells elicit tend to be more vivid and emotional.” So, as we reckon with our not particularly vivid and still mostly homebound existences, why not use scent to relive the visceral joys of wild nights spent surrounded by friends and strangers at bars and nightclubs? A collection of fragrances from the industry’s top noses claim to help with just that, and contain notes of juniper, leather and tobacco meant to evoke blurry scenes of jostling bodies and neon lights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Zraick
title: Police Charge Man With Hate Crimes in Sunday Attacks on 7 Asian Women
description: The women were attacked in a spree of violence in Manhattan on Sunday, the police said. The assailant’s image was captured by surveillance cameras.
content: A 28-year-old Manhattan resident was arrested and charged with hate crimes Wednesday evening in connection with a two-hour spree of attacks on women of Asian descent in Manhattan over the weekend, another example of a grim wave of violence against Asian Americans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Dig Right In!
description: Dylan Schiff’s puzzle pushes boundaries.
content: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Please welcome back Dylan Schiff, who is making his second appearance in the New York Times Crossword today. Mr. Schiff’s debut puzzle, which was published a little over a year ago, demonstrates his talent for noticing interesting patterns in words, and his follow-up effort makes good on the promise of that first outing.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Pilot Watches With a Bold, Utilitarian Aesthetic
description: Designed with aviators in mind, these timepieces are wearable for the earthbound as well.
content: While the label denotes a target audience united by profession, the specific attributes of a pilot watch can vary from brand to brand. Bell & Ross provides an exemplar of the category with its BR 03-92 Golden Heritage: The bold numbers are highly legible, the large screw-lock crown is easily wound and the crystal surface is coated to be anti-reflective and scratch resistant. What’s more, the square-cased model mimics the gauges in an aircraft. The other three here, from Rolex, Tag Heuer and Omega, also stress utility with their prominent crowns and dials that would benefit a wearer too focused on the task at hand to fiddle with their watch. At the same time, any one from this crop would make for an appealing statement piece, even if you don’t often find yourself in a cockpit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx
title: How Would You Describe the State of Our Union?
description: President Biden delivered his first State of the Union address on Tuesday. How do you think the country is doing right now?
content: President Biden delivered his first State of the Union address on Tuesday night before a joint session of Congress. The speech came at a tense moment in modern history, as Russia’s invasion of Ukraine continued and bombs rained down on Kyiv, Ukraine’s capital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Remote Work Doesn’t Have to Be the ‘Mommy Track’
description: Despite the hand-wringing of some commentary.
content: As Covid case rates drop precipitously around much of the country, some corporate executives and the Biden administration appear to be pushing toward a return to the office. While most Americans can’t work remotely in the first place (about 60 percent, according to Pew Research), those who say they’re happiest working from home are women and Black Americans, according to a recent Harris Poll survey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari
title: H&M halts sales in Russia after the invasion of Ukraine.
description: The announcement followed similar decisions from tech companies, oil giants and Hollywood studios.
content: H&M Group, one of the biggest sellers of clothing in the world, said on Wednesday that it was temporarily pausing all sales in Russia, joining a growing list of companies rethinking their ties to the country after its invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: The State of the Union: Together, if Only for a Few Minutes
description: President Biden brought a cheerleading tone to a normal-ish address for very abnormal times.
content: When he took office, President Joseph R. Biden Jr. likely hoped that a year later, he could begin his first State of the Union address with an inspirational exhortation about a united country rejecting authoritarianism, provoking standing ovations and flag-waving from both sides of the congressional aisle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: In Symbolic Vote, Senate Rejects Vaccine Mandate for Health Workers
description: Republicans forced the vote even though the measure has no chance of enactment, as part of an election-year effort to use pandemic precautions as a political weapon against Democrats.
content: WASHINGTON — The Senate voted on Wednesday to roll back President Biden’s vaccine mandate for health care workers at federally funded facilities, in a symbolic move orchestrated by Republicans who are pushing to weaponize pandemic precautions against Democrats in this year’s midterm congressional elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Rob Szypko, Sydney Harper, Luke Vander Ploeg, Paige Cowett, John Ketchum, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
title: How Europe Came Around on Sanctions
description: Will the bloc’s penalties be enough to help end Russia’s war on Ukraine?
content: As Russian forces bombard Ukraine’s cities and strike civilian areas with increasingly powerful weapons, the European Union has adopted the largest package of sanctions ever imposed on a single country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cecilia Kang
title: A coalition of state attorneys general opens an investigation into TikTok.
description: The group is looking into the Chinese-owned video site for the harms it may pose to younger users.
content: A bipartisan group of state attorneys general announced on Wednesday that it had opened an investigation into TikTok and potential harms that the popular social media app may pose to younger users.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.

title: I Love London Theater. But Not London Theatergoing.

title: Mayor in Ukraine asks his city’s residents whether they wish to fight or surrender.
description: The mayor of Konotop, in northeastern Ukraine, said Russian soldiers had told him they would “raze the city to the ground with their artillery.”
content: The city of Konotop, in northeastern Ukraine, was the scene of a tense confrontation between residents and Russian troops, who the mayor said had threatened to destroy the city if it didn’t surrender.

title: Reports of civilian casualties rise in Ukraine, but exact counts remain uncertain.
description: As is often the case in war zones, tolls diverged. It was not immediately possible for The New York Times to provide an independent estimate.
content: As the bombing of civilian targets in Ukraine intensified on Wednesday, reports of civilian casualties escalated. It was not immediately possible for The New York Times to provide an independent estimate, and, as is often the case in war zones, reports diverged.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany
title: Millions for Crypto Start-Ups, No Real Names Necessary
description: Investors give money to pseudonymous developers. Venture capitalists back founders without learning their real names. What happens when they need to know?
content: For months, cryptocurrency enthusiasts poured hundreds of millions of dollars into a project called Wonderland, which claimed to provide a system of exchange for the murky world of decentralized finance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: At the State of the Union, Dressing for Ukrainian Solidarity
description: Red, white (yellow) and blue were on display as President Biden addressed Congress.
content: The presidential State of the Union address has always been a moment of political theater on a grand scale, full of soaring rhetoric and pageantry as well as policy and partisanship. Only recently has it also become a costume drama, with supporting players using visual cues to make their voices, and positions, heard — even though they aren’t officially supposed to be speaking at all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathleen Lynn
title: Plainfield, N.J.: A Diverse City With Historic Housing
description: The city’s ornate Victorian homes are more affordable than those in surrounding areas. But that’s only one of the reasons that people move here.
content: Like many older cities, Plainfield, N.J., went through difficult times in the second half of the 20th century, including a deadly riot in 1967, known as the Plainfield Rebellion. But the Union County city weathered those storms and is now better known for the handsome Victorian and Tudor-style homes built during its heyday in the late 1800s and early 1900s, when Wall Street bankers and other affluent New Yorkers followed the train line out to exurbia. Those vintage homes have long been more affordable than similar properties in nearby suburbs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Phil Mickelson’s Setbacks Keep Coming, and Tiger Woods Gets a Bonus
description: Mickelson previously boasted that he won the PGA Tour’s new program that pays the most popular pros, but the embattled golfer finished behind his rival once again.
content: ORLANDO, Fla. — In an off-the-course chapter of the enduring rivalry between Tiger Woods and Phil Mickelson, Woods once again bested Mickelson.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Biden’s Fed Nominees Are Frozen as One Faces Republican Questions

content: President Biden’s nominee for the top banking cop at the Federal Reserve was expected to face Republican backlash over her views on how finance should guard against climate change and her preference for tough regulation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Cisneros forces Cuellar into a runoff, a sign of liberal strength in a key Texas congressional race.
description: In the most closely watched House primary, Representative Henry Cuellar, a longtime Democratic incumbent, was forced into a runoff with Jessica Cisneros, a 28-year-old progressive lawyer.
content: A 28-year-old liberal immigration lawyer was headed for a runoff in May with Representative Henry Cuellar, South Texas’s 17-year incumbent, after neither candidate on Tuesday was able to muster 50 percent of the vote in the state’s most closely watched House primary.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Stop-Start Schooling

title: Nevada Gov. Steve Sisolak Is Accosted by Man Who Threatens to Hang Him
description: The governor was dining with his wife and daughter at a Las Vegas restaurant when a man asked him for a photo together before going into a profanity-laced rant.
content: Gov. Steve Sisolak of Nevada was accosted at a Mexican restaurant in Las Vegas on Sunday by a man who recorded the confrontation in a video in which he threatens to “string you up by a lamppost.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: As oil soars, OPEC and its allies decline to offer relief.
description: The oil cartel known as OPEC Plus said it would continue the strategy agreed to in July, rubber-stamping a 400,000-barrel-a-day production increase for April.
content: With the price of a barrel of oil soaring, the group of oil producers known as OPEC Plus declined to take steps to cool the market at its monthly meeting on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lena Wilson
title: ‘Hell Is Empty’ Review: Sins of the Father
description: In this bare-bones horror film, a young woman joins a cult and eventually defies its patriarch.
content: In horror, the burden of taking down the patriarchy — whether symbolized by a group of violent men or just one foreboding male monster — often rests on the humble shoulders of a young woman. “Hell Is Empty,” a film by the director Jo Shaffer about a girl who haplessly joins and eventually dismantles a remote cult, follows this tradition. Unfortunately, its heroine is just one in a series of underwritten characters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: I See Three Scenarios for How This War Ends
description: Every day that Putin refuses to stop, we get closer to the gates of hell.
content: The battle for Ukraine unfolding before our eyes has the potential to be the most transformational event in Europe since World War II and the most dangerous confrontation for the world since the Cuban missile crisis. I see three possible scenarios for how this story ends. I call them “the full-blown disaster,” “the dirty compromise” and “salvation.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Boeing and Ford suspend operations in Russia.

content: Two major U.S. manufacturers, Boeing and Ford Motor, have suspended their business activities in Russia as the country escalated its war in Ukraine.

title: Explosive Scenes as New Zealand Police Move to End Weekslong Occupation
description: Fires and violence at a protest opposing vaccine mandates were a rare sight in a country known for its relative serenity and stability.
content: For more than three weeks, hundreds of protesters have disabled the center of New Zealand’s capital city, occupying the area in front of Parliament and issuing increasingly violent threats to politicians and other public figures in an ostensible battle against the country’s vaccine mandates.
source.name: The New York Times

content: Could three seconds a day of resistance exercise really increase muscular strength?

title: Winter Season at City Ballet: ‘Now Is the Time for a New Generation’
description: The season saw more farewells, from principals Teresa Reichlen and Gonzalo Garcia, along with a rush of talent from the recently promoted.
content: I had a recurring thought during New York City Ballet’s winter season: Thank god for Jovani Furlan. He lifts the mood when he dances. He’s sexy without being cheesy, an attentive partner and joyfully attuned to the moment. George Balanchine used to ask his dancers: “What are you waiting for? What are you saving it for?” If Furlan is saving anything, I can’t tell.

content: The conductor Michael Tilson Thomas announced on Wednesday that he would step down as artistic director of the New World Symphony, a prestigious training orchestra for young artists in Miami that he helped found, as he battles an aggressive form of brain cancer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt and Julian E. Barnes

content: A career National Security Council staff member under President Donald J. Trump, who was pushed out of her position after she refused to go along with an effort to use the powers of the federal government to silence one of Mr. Trump’s chief critics, has been rehired for the post by President Biden, two people briefed on the matter said on Wednesday.

author: By Andriy Yermak
title: As I Write, President Zelensky Is Beside Me. Please, Help Us Show Putin the Mistake He Has Made.
description: Nothing less than our freedom — and yours — is at stake.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — In launching a war on our country, President Vladimir Putin claimed Russia would “de-Nazify” and free Ukraine. But Ukraine — a nation that lost as many as eight million lives in World War II, a country that has a Jewish president — does not need to be freed from the liberated path it has chosen.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Senators want to know if Russia can use cryptocurrencies to skirt sanctions.
description: Four Democrats have asked Treasury officials to explain how they’re overseeing digital assets while Russia is largely frozen out of traditional commerce.
content: Four U.S. senators want Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen to explain how her department plans to get cryptocurrency companies and other digital-asset middlemen to do their part in enforcing economic sanctions against Russia.

author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Lynsey Addario
title: 15,000 Are Sheltering in Kyiv’s Subway
description: People sleep three or four to a mattress and plastic food bags litter the scene, while mothers search endlessly on their phones for news of the war.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — As the escalator glides down the final few yards into the subway stop deep in Kyiv’s normally immaculate mass transit system, a sprawl of foam mattresses, suitcases and plastic bags filled with food comes into view. The space is surprisingly quiet, almost silent, despite the 200 or so people camped there to escape the bombing and artillery fire above.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex W. Palmer
title: They Came to Help Migrants. Now, Europe Has Turned on Them.
description: As the legal ordeal of two aid workers shows, anti-migrant attitudes in Greece and across Europe have hardened — to the point that the helpers have become political targets.
content: On a cold night in February 2018, Sara Mardini and Seán Binder sat in a jeep on the rocky headlands of Lesbos, their eyes on the water. As volunteers for Emergency Response Center International, a small humanitarian aid group, Mardini and Binder were looking for signs of incoming migrant boats, so they could alert the Greek coast guard and search-and-rescue groups to dispatch assistance. They made an unlikely pair: Binder is a soft-spoken Irishman, with broad shoulders and a mop of black hair; Mardini, a Syrian refugee with a nose ring and a preference for leather jackets. But they shared an easy camaraderie, bound by their playful energy and a fiercely serious devotion to their work.
source.name: The New York Times

description: Residents of Odessa, Ukraine’s critical port on the Black Sea, are bracing as Russian naval and ground forces approach. “Every day they make it seem like today is the day,” the mayor said.
content: ODESSA, Ukraine—Sparks fly day and night at the rail yard of Odessa’s tram authority, where men in coveralls are slicing up old steel rails and welding them into barricades called “hedgehogs” to stop Russian tanks.

author: By Sophie Haigney
title: Why Do We Watch the Weather on TV While It Is Happening Just Outside?
description: The strange allure of watching someone else stand in the blizzard.
content: Late in January, in Riverhead, N.Y., a local newscaster stood on a main street in falling snow. It was early morning, still dark out, the day of a much anticipated blizzard, and she gestured at how much snow had already accumulated on the street. Someone in the studio said, “It’s coming down.” She paused and affirmed, “It is coming down.” This was, in fact, already aggressively obvious: Snow was blowing all around her.
